byline.contributor: Jess Bidgood reported from Augusta, and Richard Pérez-Peña from New York.
byline.original: By JESS BIDGOOD and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

abstract: Geraldine  A Largay, who died of exposure and starvation after becoming lost in Maine while hiking alone on Appalachian Trail in summer 2013, chronicled her journey in notebook; her remains were not found until 2015, less than mile from trail, solving mystery that pained her family and stymied teams of experienced rescuers.
lead_paragraph: “When you find my body, please call my husband George and my daughter Kerry,” Ms. Largay, 66, wrote in her diary after she became lost while hiking in Maine.

headline.main: Geraldine Largay’s Wrong Turn: Death on the Appalachian Trail
headline.print_headline: ‘When You Find My Body’: Fatal Turn on the Appalachian Trail

snippet: “When you find my body, please call my husband George and my daughter Kerry,” Ms. Largay, 66, wrote in her diary after she became lost while hiking in Maine.
